title: How Neutrophils Turn from Cancer Fighters to Helpers
summary: Researchers at the University of Geneva and the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research discovered that neutrophils, a common type of immune cell, can be reprogrammed by tumors to support cancer growth. Normally, neutrophils act as early defenders against infections, but in cancer, they are recruited by tumors and start producing a molecule called CCL3. This chemokine promotes tumor growth instead of fighting it. The study, published in Cancer Cell, involved overcoming technical challenges to manipulate the CCL3 gene specifically in neutrophils. When CCL3 was removed, neutrophils no longer aided tumor growth, though they still functioned normally elsewhere. This finding suggests that CCL3 could serve as a signal for tracking cancer progression across various cancer types, building on earlier research about macrophages. The work highlights the complex interactions within the tumor environment and offers insights into potential new targets for cancer therapy.

background_read: Cancer involves uncontrolled cell growth forming tumors, which exist in a complex microenvironment with various cell types like immune cells. Neutrophils are key immune cells that usually combat pathogens but can be hijacked in cancer. Previous studies, such as one in 2023 on macrophages, linked gene expression to disease progression. This new research explores how tumors alter neutrophils to produce CCL3, a molecule that promotes growth, offering insights into cancer biology and potential diagnostic tools. Understanding these interactions helps scientists develop targeted therapies to improve patient outcomes.
